"Of course, this diplomatic move tided affairs over" (awkward phrasing)
"We were to enter an untried and an unknown field" (awkward phrasing)
"It was fitting that we have a final joyous meeting" (incorrect verb tense; should be "had")
"We were several miles from the shore and nothing in sight indicated that we had reached a place of any importance" (awkward phrasing)
"So our first impressions on coming on deck were that we had run aground" (awkward phrasing)
"We were awakened by the loud, sharp ringing of the ship's bells" (missing past tense in original)
"We clambered into the wagon and were soon lost in the depths of foliage" (awkward phrasing)
"The muscles of the mules stood out like whip-cords under the skin as they drew us forward" (awkward phrasing)
"The reign of force was at an end; it was going out with them; the reign of peace had begun; it was coming in with us" (awkward phrasing)

[GRAMMAR]: "The work of the teachers was, in short; to 'make the English language the basis of instruction in the public schools.'" (Misuse of semicolon after "in short")
[PUNCTUATION]: "We landed, but it was in a method new to us and one not usually employed by the traveling public." (Awkward phrasing and missing comma after "public")
[SPELLING]: "straddled the neck of a Filipino standing in the water and was held by ankles to be steadied" (Missing article "the" before "ankles")
[SYNTAX]: "Each of us then straddled the neck of a Filipino standing in the water and was held by ankles to be steadied while our biped mounts proceeded to the shore." (Cumbersome and awkward sentence structure)
[LEXICON]: "The boat's crew elevated their trousers' legs also and slided down into the water." ("Slided" is nonstandard; "slid" is correct)

[LOGIC]: The transition from the emotional scene of the women to the description of Philippine towns is abrupt and lacks a clear connection.

[GRAMMAR]: "we forewent the pleasures of his oratory and turned our attention to the savory odor of lamb, chicken, and roast pig that came slyly stealing up our nostrils to send us nerve dispatches about the gastronomic delights of our not far distant future." (awkward phrasing and overuse of adjectives)

"A second attempt to follow the music met with results similar to the first, and during the third attempt, which seemed to be trembling on the verge of a failure, St. Vitus let go my companion and seized me with such vigor that she, who was small even for a Filipino, was gathered up bodily and taken around the room at such a pace that her toes touched the floor only at far distant intervals." (overly complex sentence structure)

"It was easy to see that the Filipinos really had a good deal of money; that they liked to dress was apparent; and that they believed in a table loaded with good things was a fact to which all of us were enthusiastic witnesses." (awkward and repetitive structure)
[SYNTAX]: "for, as soon as the pleasant task of one dish was completed by any one, the next was served him at once regardless of the progress made by the others at the table." (awkward structure and unclear pronoun reference)
"My eyes must have told the story that my lips could not utter in Spanish, for she smiled upon me sweetly, arose, and put her hand upon my shoulder." (awkward transition between clauses)

"The process of beautifying and improving the city which is constantly going on bids fair to give us at no distant day a city of which we may well be proud." (awkward phrasing and outdated expression)
[LEXICON]: "No matter of what materials a dish is composed, just so long as it is sweet, it is dulce." (redundant phrasing)
